title: Teaching Your Child Math When You're Not Good at Math
description: Practical strategies for parents who struggle with math themselves but want to help their children succeed.

content.intro: "I'm terrible at math" is something many parents say. But you can still help your child succeed at math – even if you struggled yourself.

sections.text: Good News: You Don't Need to Be a Math Expert
Your role isn't to be the teacher. It's to be:

items: A supporter: Create conditions for learning
A cheerleader: Encourage effort and progress
A facilitator: Connect them with resources
A model: Show that adults learn too

rows: Normalizes math avoidance, suggests it's genetic

sections.text: You don't need math skills for this. Set a regular time, quiet space, and routine for math practice.
Sit nearby while they work. You don't need to solve problems – just being there provides accountability and emotional support.

items: "Tell me how you're thinking about this"
"What do you think you should do first?"
"Does that answer make sense to you?"

sections.text: "I don't remember this – let's figure it out together." This models that learning is lifelong and problems are solvable.
Khan Academy, YouTube tutorials, math apps – let experts explain concepts. Your job is to make sure your child uses these resources.
Research shows that parent involvement matters more than parent math ability. Your presence, encouragement, and structure have more impact than your ability to solve algebra problems.
Dealing with Your Own Math Anxiety

items: Acknowledge it privately, don't share it with your child
Remember that elementary math is different from what made you anxious
Focus on effort and process, not correct answers
Celebrate your child's wins as your wins too

sections.text: If your child needs more instruction than you can provide:

items: Request extra help from the teacher
Look into tutoring (many affordable options exist)
Use adaptive learning apps that teach and practice
Ask family members or friends who are comfortable with math

faq.question: Should I admit I'm not good at math?
faq.answer: Be honest but careful. "This is tricky for me too" is better than "I'm terrible at math." Model a growth mindset rather than a fixed one.

faq.question: What if my child asks questions I can't answer?
faq.answer: "Great question – let's look that up together." It's fine not to know. What matters is showing how to find answers.

faq.question: Can my math anxiety transfer to my child?
faq.answer: Yes, this is documented. But awareness helps. Focus on positive framing, avoid expressing frustration with math, and let your child see you learning.
